repnme.cdata!: Yugoslavia - Tenth and Eleventh Highway Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The Tenth and Eleventh Highway Projects
            in Yugoslavia covered all eight republics and provinces
            which make up the Yugoslav Federation. The Tenth Highway
            Project focused primarily on the lesser-developed areas of
            the country and included five borrowers - Kosovo,
            Montenegro, Macedonia, Vojvodina and Bosnia-Herzegovina. The
            Eleventh Highway Project helped maintain the impetus
            established by the previous Seventh, Eighth and Ninth
            Highway Projects on improvements to key sections of the
            Trans-Yugoslav Highway (TYH). The Tenth and Eleventh Highway
            Projects were both implemented during a period of structural
            adjustment which involved a substantial reduction in the
            level of expenditures on roads. The Tenth Highway Project
            introduced a sector-lending approach which provided some
            flexibility in adjusting to the reduced level of funds and
            in redefining priorities. Some of the lessons learned
            included: 1) Despite up to a two-year delay in the
            completion of most items, most of the road improvement
            programs was completed as originally planned; 2) In
            hindsight, the Bank should have coordinated the disbursement
            of co-financing funds with its own disbursements on the
            project; 3) As in previous projects, equipment procurement
            was delayed because of difficulties in obtaining import
            licenses and a substantial part of the allocation for
            equipment under the Eleventh Project was cancelled; and 4)
            Closer attention might have been paid to design standards at
            appraisal and revisions might have been introduced during
            the SAP discussion.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Tenth Highway Project provides for
            direct participation by the Bank in a 3-year (mid-1979 to
            mid-1982) slice of the 1979-85 highway development programs
            of the five participating Republics/Provinces. These
            development programs, which result from the recommendations
            of Highway Master Plan Studies which each agency carried out
            cover: the construction of new roads; the reconstruction and
            rehabilitation of existing roads; the purchase of
            specialized equipment to assist the Roads Organizations in
            monitoring traffic and in acquiring and processing data
            related to the operations of their networks of interregional
            and regional (including primary, secondary and feeder)
            roads; and personnel training to assist the Roads
            Organizations in improving their standards of administering
            and maintaining their roads networks. Benefits of the
            highway sector loan would be improved communications and the
            lowering of transportation costs within the five
            Republics/Provinces. All sectors of the economy will benefit
            due to these improvements, and many outlying regions will be
            better integrated with the main traffic system, thus
            permitting a balanced development of the less-developed
            parts of Yugoslavia.
